{{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox political party | country = the United Kingdom | name = Left Alternative | logo = | leader = Collective leadership ([[Central Committee]]) | foundation = 2008 | ideology = | position = | international = | european = | europarl = | colours = | colorcode = red | headquarters = London | website = }}
'''Left Alternative''' was a UK political party resulting from the split within [[Respect – The Unity Coalition]] in late 2007.
The party operated in [[England and Wales]] and was backed by the [[Socialist Workers Party (UK)|Socialist Workers Party]] (SWP). Soon after the split, the electoral label '''Left List''' was adopted and this label faced its first major electoral test in the [[London mayoral election, 2008|London mayoral elections]] and [[London Assembly election, 2008|London Assembly elections]] on 1 May 2008. [[Lindsey German]], the Mayoral candidate, came seventh and in both the Mayoral and Assembly elections, Left List received less than 1% of the vote, well down on Respect's performance in 2004. The name Left Alternative was subsequently adopted.
==History== Respect was created in January 2004,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3788125.stm BBC News]</ref> using the issue of the [[Iraq War|war in Iraq]] to mobilise its vote. Beyond this issue, it attempted to have a broad [[socialism|socialist]] agenda. Respect allows its members to hold membership of other political organisations and notably included the SWP. Respect's most high-profile figure has been [[George Galloway]], then [[Respect - The Unity Coalition|Respect]] [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Bethnal Green and Bow]], who was expelled from the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] in 2003 for "bringing the party into disrepute".
===The crisis in Respect=== {{Main|Respect - The Unity Coalition#The split in Respect|l1=The split in Respect}} In September 2007, Galloway wrote a letter to Respect's national council members saying that the party was "too disorganised" and "faced oblivion" unless it reformed its internal party management.<ref>[http://www.themuslimweekly.com/fullstoryview.aspx?NewsID=215082B330A483E173B045F1&MENUID=HOMENEWS&DESCRIPTION=UK%20News Galloway slams own Respect party], ''[[The Muslim Weekly]]'', 14 September 2007</ref> The letter also criticised the amount of money spent on the Organising for Fighting Unions conference and on an intervention at the Pride London [[LGBT]] rights event.
The letter was the opening shot in a dispute in Respect initially between Galloway and his supporters (including founding member [[Salma Yaqoob]]) on one side, and supporters of the SWP on the other. However the arguments later began to affect all of the membership including those not in the SWP or close to Galloway or Yaqoob. In particular, Galloway called for the appointment of a National Organiser, who would support the National Secretary, [[John Rees (activist)|John Rees]] (then an SWP member). The SWP perceived this to be an attempt to undermine John Rees who was the dominant voice for the SWP within Respect's leadership. A letter from their Central Committee stated: "The SWP believed that the post was created to undermine Respect National Secretary John Rees."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpgb.org.uk/worker/692/swp%20party%20notes.htm |title=From the SWP's Party Notes |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018030211/http://www.cpgb.org.uk/worker/692/swp%20party%20notes.htm |archivedate=18 October 2007 |df= }}</ref>
In the course of the dispute, the SWP expelled three members who sided with Galloway: [[Kevin Ovenden]] and [[Rob Hoveman]], who both worked for George Galloway, and Nick Wrack, who was nominated for the position of National Organiser.
On 3 November 2007, Galloway's side announced plans to hold a "[[Respect Renewal]]" conference on 17 November, the same day as the planned national conference of Respect. The Respect Renewal conference was an open event and organisers claim 350 people attended. This figure was disputed by [[Chris Harman]] in ''[[International Socialism (magazine)|International Socialism]]''. The Respect national conference, which went ahead on the same day was attended by 270 delegates from 49 local branches and 17 student groups, as well as 90 observers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harman|first=Chris|url=http://www.isj.org.uk/index.php4?id=396&issue=117|title=The Crisis in Respect|work=[[International Socialism (magazine)|International Socialism]]|year=2008|accessdate=5 January 2008}}</ref>
Linda Smith, Respect's national chair at the time of the split, has claimed: "The sectarianism and ‘control freak’ methods of the SWP have led us to a situation where Respect is irretrievably split."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://respectrenewal.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=20|title=Renewing Respect}}</ref> The SWP has attributed the split to a shift to the right by George Galloway and his allies, motivated by electoralism (placing election-winning above other principles). This, say the SWP leadership, led to attacks on the SWP as the most prominent left group in Respect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swp.org.uk/respect_cc.php |title=The record: The Socialist Workers Party and Respect |author=SWP Central Committee Statement |date=3 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907150924/http://www.swp.org.uk/respect_cc.php |archivedate= 7 September 2008 |df= }}</ref>
===Left List emerges=== The [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] refused to take a side in the split and therefore continued to recognise Linda Smith as the Nominating Officer for Respect.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.electoralcommission.gov.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfm?frmGB=1&frmPartyID=467&frmType=partydetail|title=Register of political parties: Respect—The Unity Coalition|accessdate=2008-03-17}}</ref> This means that her signature is required for candidates wishing to use the electoral label "Respect" (and similar registered names) on ballot papers in UK elections. A letter from the Electoral Commission to Linda Smith on 23 January 2008, set out its position on the split, following confusion on the matter from both sides.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistunity.com/?p=1617|publisher=Socialist Unity|title=RESPECT—SWP can't use the name}}</ref>
Following the split, the side that included the SWP (but not Galloway or Linda Smith) nominated candidates in two district council by-elections. They could not use the name "Respect" on ballot papers without the signature of the nominating officer. Instead, both had no label on the ballot papers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.preston.gov.uk/elections/ElectionWard.asp?ward=94|title=Preston City Council Electoral Ward Nominees}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walthamforest.gov.uk/index/council/elections/leyton-by-election/leyton-by-election-candidates.htm|title=Statement as to persons nominated|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070620191530/http://www.walthamforest.gov.uk/index/council/elections/leyton-by-election/leyton-by-election-candidates.htm|archivedate=20 June 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
This side in the Respect split announced that in the [[London mayoral election, 2008|London mayoral elections]] planned for 1 May 2008 it would stand [[Lindsey German]] for mayor (Respect's candidate in 2004 and chosen as Respect's candidate in 2007 prior to the schism) and candidates for the London Assembly, elected on the same date. It announced that its candidates would contest these elections under a new electoral label, the Left List, since Linda Smith had not allowed them to be listed on ballot papers as Respect candidates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.respectcoalition.org/?ite=1833 |title=Respect's Left List launches GLA challenge |publisher=Respect—the Unity Coalition |accessdate=2008-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506072756/http://www.respectcoalition.org/?ite=1833 |archivedate= 6 May 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfm?frmGB=1&frmPartyID=818&frmType=partydetail|title=Register of political parties: Left List}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=14397|title=Why Respect is Standing as 'Left List' in London|accessdate=2008-03-17|publisher=[[Socialist Worker]]|date=2008-03-15}}</ref>
The Left List contested every constituency and stood on the London-wide proportional representation list. At the council elections on 1 May 2008, the Left List also contested seats as the Left List or the Left Party, Maxine Bowler in Burngreave, Sheffield.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.respectcoalition.org/?ite=1822 |title=Respect announces Left List for Mayoral and GLA elections |publisher=[[Respect Party|Respect - The Unity Coalition]] |date=2008-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322212630/http://www.respectcoalition.org/?ite=1822 |archivedate=22 March 2008 |df= }}</ref> [[Respect Renewal]] stood in the City and East London constituency as well as contesting the London-wide list. George Galloway headed the London-wide party list, and Respect Renewal candidates stood under the name Respect (George Galloway).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.respectrenewal.org/content/view/211/1/ |title=We Can Win In East London This May |publisher=[[Respect Renewal]] |date=2008-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327181236/http://www.respectrenewal.org/content/view/211/1 |archivedate=27 March 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.respectrenewal.org/images/stories/downloads/respectspecialeditionmar08.pdf|format=PDF|title=Respect Newspaper Special Edition|publisher=[[Respect Renewal]]|date=2008-03-15}}</ref>
Both factions of Respect suffered as a result and together failed to reach the previous number of votes.
=== Left Alternative === The organisation's website began to display the title Left Alternative in late June 2008. On 10 September 2008 John Rees and Lindsey German resigned from the Left Alternative National Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thecommune.wordpress.com/2008/09/10/rees-and-german-resign-from-left-alternative-leadership/|title=rees and german resign from left alternative leadership|publisher=The Commune|accessdate=2008-09-10}}</ref><ref name="SWP dumps John Rees">[http://www.cpgb.org.uk/worker/737/swpdumps.html SWP dumps John Rees] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925044309/http://www.cpgb.org.uk/worker/737/swpdumps.html |date=25 September 2008 }}</ref> Most elected councillors who had joined Left List at the time of the split from Respect subsequently defected to other parties, mainly Labour, over the course of 2008.<ref name="SWP dumps John Rees"/> In 2008, one Left List councillor defected to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]. In June of that year, the three remaining Left List councillors in Tower Hamlets, including the Chair and Nominating Officer of the Left List, defected to the Labour Party as did one Respect Renewal councillor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastlondonadvertiser.co.uk/content/towerhamlets/advertiser/news/story.aspx?brand=ELAOnline&category=news&tBrand=northlondon24&tCategory=newsela&itemid=WeED24%20Jun%202008%2019%3A44%3A39%3A473|title= New blow for Galloway as four more Respect members defect}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastlondonadvertiser.co.uk/search/story.aspx?brand=ELAOnline&category=News&itemid=WeED14%20Feb%202008%2014:33:40:697&tBrand=ELAOnline&tCategory=search|title=Galloway defector signs up to join Tory party}}</ref>
The organisation's website ceased operation in mid-2009. The party deregistered from the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] Register of Political Parties in April 2010.

{{distinguish|liberal conservatism|conservative liberalism}} {{Conservatism US |Schools}} {{Libertarianism in the United States sidebar|Related}} '''Libertarian conservatism''' or '''conservative libertarianism''' is a [[political philosophy]] and [[ideology]] that combines [[Right-libertarianism|right-libertarian]] [[politics]] and [[Conservatism|conservative values]]. Libertarian conservatism advocates the greatest possible economic liberty and the least possible government regulation of social life, mirroring ''[[laissez faire|laissez-faire]]'' [[classical liberalism|liberalism]], but harnesses this to a belief in a more traditional and conservative social philosophy emphasizing authority and duty.{{sfn|Heywood|2015|p=37}} Libertarian conservatism prioritizes [[liberty]] as its main emphasis, promoting [[free expression]], [[freedom of choice]] and [[free market capitalism]] to achieve [[Social conservatism|socially]] and [[Cultural conservatism|culturally conservative]] ends as they reject [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] [[Social engineering (political science)|social engineering]],<ref name=Piper>J. Richard Piper, ''Ideologies and Institutions: American Conservative and Liberal Governance Prescriptions Since 1933'', [[Rowman & Littlefield]], 1997, [https://books.google.com/books?id=u93Mj3A-tH8C&pg=PA110 pp. 110–111], {{ISBN|0847684598}}, {{ISBN|978-0847684595}}.</ref> or in the opposite way but not excluding the above, libertarian conservatism could be understood as promoting [[civil society]] through conservative institutions and authority - as family, fatherland, religion, education - in the quest of libertarian ends for less state power.<ref>[https://mises.org/library/getting-libertarianism-right Getting Libertarianism Right]. [[Hans-Hermann Hoppe]]. {{ISBN|978-1-61016-690-4}}. [[Mises Institute]] Publishing.</ref>
== Philosophy == For Larry Johnston, in [[political science]], the term "libertarian conservatism" is used to refer to ideologies that combine the advocacy of economic principles such as [[fiscal discipline]], respect for [[contract]]s, defense of [[private property]] and [[free market]]s{{sfn|Johnston|2007|pp=154–56}} and the [[Traditionalist conservatism|traditional conservative]] stress on self-help and freedom of choice under a ''[[laissez-faire]]'' and [[Economic liberalism|economically liberal]] [[Capitalism|capitalist]] society with social tenets such as the importance of [[religion]] and the value of [[Religious morality|traditional morality]]{{sfn|Johnston|2007|p=154}} through a framework of [[Limited government|limited]], [[Constitutional government|constitutional]], [[representative government]].{{sfn|Johnston|2007|pp=154–155}}
For Margaret Randall, libertarian conservatism began as an expression of [[individualism]] and the demand for [[personal freedom]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Schlesinger|first=Arthur|authorlink=Arthur M. Schlesinger, Sr.|title=The Rise of the City: 1878-1898|publisher=The Academy of Political Science|date=September 1933|orig-year=1st pub. 1933|pages=454–456|chapter=Vol. 48}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Randall|first=Margaret|authorlink=Margaret Randall|title=Sandino's Daughters: Testimonies of Nicaraguan Women in Struggle|publisher=Rutgers University Press|date=January 14, 2018|orig-year=1st pub. 1995|pages=ii|chapter=Preface}}</ref>
''Freedom and Virtue: The Conservative/Libertarian Debate'', edited by George W. Carey, contains essays which describe "the tension between liberty and morality" as "the main fault line dividing the two philosophies".<ref>George W. Carey (Editor), ''Freedom & Virtue: The Conservative Libertarian Debate,'' Intercollegiate Studies Institute, 1998. {{ISBN|1-882926-19-6}}.</ref>
Nelson Hultberg wrote that there is "philosophical common ground" between libertarians and conservatives. "The true conservative movement was, from the start, a blend of political libertarianism, cultural conservatism, and non-interventionism abroad bequeathed to us via the Founding Fathers". He said that such libertarian conservatism was "hijacked" by [[neoconservatism]], "by the very enemies it was formed to fight – [[Fabian Society|Fabians]], [[New Deal]]ers, [[Welfare state|welfarists]], [[Progressivism in the United States|progressives]], globalists, interventionists, militarists, nation builders, and all the rest of the collectivist ilk that was assiduously working to destroy the Founders' Republic of States".<ref>Nelson Hultberg, [http://www.afr.org/Hultberg/122006.html "True Conservatism vs. Neo-Conservatism"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820085956/http://www.afr.org/Hultberg/122006.html|date=August 20, 2008}}, [http://afr.org "Americans for a Free Republic"] website, December 20, 2006.</ref>
[[Thomas DiLorenzo]] wrote that libertarian conservative [[Constitutionalism|constitutionalists]] believe that the way to limit government is to enforce the [[United States Constitution]]. However, DiLorenzo criticized them by writing: "The fatal flaw in the thinking of the libertarian/conservative constitutionalists stems from their unawareness or willful ignorance of how the founders themselves believed the Constitution could be enforced: by the citizens of the free, independent, and sovereign states, not the federal judiciary". He wrote that the powers accrued to the federal government during the [[American Civil War]] overthrew the Constitution of 1787.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/dilorenzo/dilorenzo74.html|title=Constitutional Futility|last=DiLorenzo|first=Thomas|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref>
In the 1950's [[Frank Meyer (political philosopher)|Frank Meyer]], a prominent contributor to the ''[[National Review]]'', called his own combination libertarianism and conservatism as "[[fusionism]]".<ref name="Feser">Edward Feser, [http://archive.lewrockwell.com/orig/feser2.html "What Libertarianism Isn't"], [[Lew Rockwell.com]], December 22, 2001.</ref><ref>Ralph Raico, [https://mises.org/story/1784 "Is Libertarianism Amoral?"], ''New Individualist Review'', Volume 3, Number 3, Fall 1964, 29–36; republished by [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]], April 4, 2005.</ref>
In the 1990s, [[Lew Rockwell]], [[Murray Rothbard]] and others described their libertarian conservative views as [[paleolibertarianism]].<ref name=LR>{{cite journal|last1=Rockwell|first1=Lew|title=The Case for Paleo-libertarianism|journal=Liberty|issue=January 1990|pages=34–38|url=http://www.pericles.press/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Liberty_Magazine.pdf}}.</ref> They continued libertarian opposition to "all forms of government intervention – economic, cultural, social, international", but also upholding cultural conservatism in social thought and behavior. They opposed a licentious libertarianism which advocated "freedom from bourgeois morality, and social authority".<ref name=LR/> Rockwell later stated that they dropped that self-description because people confused it with [[paleoconservatism]], which they rejected.<ref name=lewinterview>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/liberal-post-interview.html|title=Do You Consider Yourself a Libertarian?|last=Johnsson|first=Kenny|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref><ref name=lrc>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/paleoism.html|title=What I Learned From Paleoism|last=Rockwell|first=Llewellyn H.|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref>
Laurence M. Vance wrote: "Some libertarians consider libertarianism to be a lifestyle rather than a political philosophy... They apparently don't know the difference between libertarianism and [[libertinism]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/vance/vance133.html|title=Is Ron Paul Wrong on Abortion?|last=Vance|first=Laurence|date=January 29, 2008|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 1, 2008}}</ref>
[[Friedrich Hayek]], [[Ludwig von Mises]], [[Milton Friedman]], [[Richard Posner]], [[Richard Epstein]] and [[Albert Jay Nock]] have been described as libertarian conservatives.<ref name=Piper/><ref>[https://mises.org/library/cultural-thought-ludwig-von-mises-0 Cultural Thought of Ludwig von Mises]. [[Journal of Libertarian Studies]]. 1991. Lew Rockwell and Jeffrey Tucker. Mises Institute.</ref> Former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Congressman]] [[Ron Paul]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/orig8/mafaldo1.html|title=The Conservative Case for Ron Paul|last=Mafaldo|first=Lucas|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> and his son [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Rand Paul]] have been described as combining libertarian and conservative "[[small government]]" ideas and showing how the Constitution defends the individual and most libertarian views.
In 1975, [[Ronald Reagan]] stated: "I believe the very heart and soul of conservatism is libertarianism". However, some libertarians criticized Reagan for un-libertarian policy positions.<ref>[http://www.reason.com/news/show/29318.html "Inside Ronald Reagan"], a ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' interview with Ronald Reagan, July 1975.</ref>
[[Edward Feser]] emphasized that libertarianism does not require individuals to reject traditional conservative values. Libertarianism supports the ideas of [[liberty]], [[privacy]] and ending the [[War on drugs|war on marijuana]] at the legal level without changing personal values.<ref name="Feser"/>
=== Economics === Libertarian conservatism subscribes to the libertarian idea of [[free market capitalism]], advocating minimal to no government interference in the [[Market (economics)|market]]. A number of libertarian conservatives favor [[Austrian economics]] and are critical of [[fiat money]], with many supporting policies like [[pay what you want]] cafes. Libertarian conservatives also advocate for ways to [[Privatization|privatize]] services run by the government, from airports to toll booths.

page.title: List of corporate collapses and scandals

revision.comment: /* List of a few major corporate collapses */ Relatively minor Australian financial services company; subtitle implies thousands of job losses, but actually talks about investors
revision.text:
A corporate collapse typically involves the [[insolvency]] or [[bankruptcy]] of a major business enterprise. A corporate scandal involves alleged or actual unethical behavior by people acting within or on behalf of a corporation. Many recent corporate collapses and scandals have involved false or inappropriate [[accounting]] of some sort (see list at [[accounting scandals]]). <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER/CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER -->
==List of a few major corporate collapses== The following list of corporations involved major collapses, through the risk of job losses or size of the business, and meant entering into [[insolvency]] or [[bankruptcy]], or being [[nationalised]] or requiring a non-market loan by a government.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- !width="100px"|Name !width="5px"|HQ !width="30px"|Date !width="60px"|Business !class="unsortable"|Causes !width="45px"|Assets |- |[[Medici Bank]] |Florence |{{dts|format=dmy|1494||}} |[[Banking]] |Owned by the [[Medici family]], it ran up large debts due to the family's profligate spending, extravagant lifestyle, and failure to control the managers, their bank went insolvent. | |- |[[Mississippi Company]] |France |{{dts|format=dmy|1720|Sep|}} |[[Colonialism]] |Scottish economist [[John Law (economist)|John Law]] convinced the French government to support a monopoly trade venture in [[Louisiana]]. He marketed shares based on great wealth, which was highly exaggerated. A speculative bubble grew and then collapsed, and Law was expelled. | |- |[[South Sea Company]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1720|Sep|}} |[[Slavery]] and [[colonialism]] |After the [[War of Spanish Succession]], the UK signed the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] 1713 with Spain, ostensibly allowing it to trade in the seas near [[South America]]. In fact, barely any trade took place as Spain renounced the Treaty, however this was concealed on the UK stock market. A speculative bubble saw the share price reach over £1000 in August 1720, but then crash in September. A Parliamentary inquiry revealed fraud among members of the government, including the [[Tory]] [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[John Aislabie]], who was sent to prison. | |- |[[Dutch East India Company]] |{{flagicon|NED|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1799|December|31}} |[[Colonialism]] |This huge early publicly listed multinational company founded in 1602 fell victim of declining markets in the late 18th century, internal corruption and excessive distribution of dividends (in excess of its profits), and finally [[Anglo-Dutch wars]]. It was nationalised by the [[Batavian Republic]] in 1796 but nevertheless closed down at the end of 1799. | |- |[[Overend, Gurney & Co]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1866|June|}} |[[Banking]] |After [[Samuel Gurney (1786–1856)|Samuel Gurney]]'s retirement, the bank invested heavily in railway stocks. It went public in 1865, but was badly affected by a general fall in stock prices. The [[Bank of England]] refused to advance money, and it collapsed. The directors were sued, but exonerated from fraud. | |- |[[Friedrich Krupp AG]] |{{flagicon|GER}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1873||}} |[[Steel]], [[metals]] |Krupp's business over-expanded, and had to take a 30m Mark loan from the Preußische Bank, the Bank of Prussia. | |- |[[Danatbank]] |{{flagicon|GER}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1931|July|13}} |[[Banking]] |At the start of the [[Great Depression]], after rumours about the solvency of the Norddeutsche Wollkämmerei & Kammgarnspinnerei, there was a [[bank run]], and Danatbank was forced into insolvency. | |- |[[Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corp]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1963|Nov|16}} |[[Commodities]] |Commodities trader [[Tino De Angelis]] defrauded clients, including the [[Bank of America]] into thinking he was trading [[vegetable oil]]. He got loans and made money using the oil as collateral. He showed inspectors tankers of water, with a bit of oil on the surface. When the fraud was exposed, the business collapsed. | |- |[[Herstatt Bank]] |{{flagicon|GER}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1974|June|26}} |[[Banking]] |Settlement risk. Counterparty banks did not receive their USD payments, where Herstatt had received DEM earlier, prior to government forced liquidation. | |- |[[Carrian Group]] |{{flagicon|HKG|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1983||}} |[[Real estate]] |Accounting fraud. An auditor was murdered, an adviser committed suicide. The largest collapse in [[Hong Kong]] history. | |- |[[Texaco]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1987|April|13}} |[[Oil]] |After a legal battle with [[Pennzoil]], whereby it was found to owe a debt of $10.5 bn, Texaco went into bankruptcy. It was later resurrected and taken over by [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]]. | |- |[[Qintex]] |{{flagicon|AUS}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1989||}} |[[Real Estate]] |Qintex CEO [[Christopher Skase]] was found to have improperly used his position to obtain management fees prior to the $1.5 billion collapse of Qintex including $700m unpaid debts. Skase absconded to the Spanish resort island of Majorca. Spain refused extradition for 10 years during which time Skase became a citizen of Dominica. | |- |[[Lincoln Savings and Loan Association]] |{{flagicon|USA|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1989||}} |[[Banking]] |Financial institution that went bust following the [[Keating Five]] scandal. | |- |[[Polly Peck]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1990|Oct|30}} |[[Electronics]], [[food]], [[textiles]] |After a raid by the UK [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|Serious Fraud Office]] in September 1990, the share price collapsed. The [[CEO]] [[Asil Nadir]] was convicted of stealing the company's money. | |- |[[Bank of Credit and Commerce International]] |{{flagicon|UK}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1991|July|5}} |[[Banking]] |Breach of US law, by owning another bank. Fraud, money laundering and larceny. | |- |[[Nordbanken]] |{{flagicon|SWE}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1991||}} |[[Banking]] |Following market deregulation, there was a housing price bubble, and it burst. As part of a general rescue as the [[Swedish banking crisis]] unfolded, Nordbanken was nationalised for 64 billion kronor. It was later merged with [[Götabanken]], which itself had to write off 37.3% of its creditors, and is now known as [[Nordea]]. | |- |[[Barings Bank]] |{{flagicon|UK}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1995|Feb|26}} |[[Banking]] |An employee in [[Singapore]], [[Nick Leeson]], traded [[futures contract|futures]], signed off on his own accounts and became increasingly indebted. The London directors were subsequently disqualified, as being unfit to run a company in ''[[Re Barings plc (No 5)]]''. | |- |[[Bre-X]] |{{flagicon|CAN}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1997||}} |[[Mining]] |After widespread reports that Bre-X had found a gold mine in [[Indonesia]], the stories were found to be fraudulent. | |- |[[Livent]] |{{flagicon|CAN}} |{{dts|format=my|1998|November}} |[[Entertainment]] |In November 1998, Livent sought bankruptcy protection in the US and Canada, claiming a debt of $334 million. Garth Howard Drabinsky, co-founder of [[Livent]], was convicted and sentenced to prison for [[fraud]] and [[forgery]]. A judgment has been obtained against [[Deloitte & Touche LLP]] in respect of Deloitte's negligence in conducting the audit for Livent's 1997 fiscal year. | |- |[[Long-Term Capital Management]] |{{flagicon|USA|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|1998|Sep|23}} |[[Hedge fund]] |After purporting to have discovered a scientific method of calculating derivative prices, LTCM lost $4.6bn in the first few months of 1998, and required state assistance to remain afloat. | $3.6 billion |- |[[The Equitable Life Assurance Society|Equitable Life Assurance Society]] |{{flagicon|UK}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2000|Dec|8}} |[[Insurance]] |The insurance company's directors unlawfully used money from people holding guaranteed annuity rate policies to subsidise people with current annuity rate policies. After a House of Lords judgment in ''[[Equitable Life Assurance Society v Hyman]]'', the Society closed. Though never technically insolvent, the UK government set up a compensation scheme for policyholders under the [[Equitable Life (Payments) Act 2010]]. | |- |[[HIH Insurance]] |{{flagicon|AUS}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|March|15}} |[[Insurance]] |In early 2000, after increase in size of the business, it was determined that the insurance company's solvency was marginal, and a small asset price change could see the insurance company become insolvent. It did. Director [[Rodney Adler]], CEO [[Ray Williams (businessman)|Ray Williams]] and others were sentenced to prison for fraudulent activity. | |- |[[Pacific Gas and Electric Company]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|April|6}} |[[Energy]] |After a change in regulation in [[California]], the company determined it was unable to continue delivering power, and despite the [[California Public Utility Commission]]'s efforts, it went into bankruptcy, leaving homes without energy. It emerged again in 2004. | |- |[[One.Tel]] |{{flagicon|AUS}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|May|29}} |[[Telecomms]] |After becoming one of the largest Australian public companies, losses of $290m were reported, the share price crashed, and it entered administration. In ''[[ASIC v Rich]]''<ref>[2009] NSWSC 1229</ref> the directors were found not to have been guilty of [[negligence]]. | |- |[[WorldCom]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|July|21}} |[[Telecomms]] |After falling share prices, and a failed share buy back scheme, it was found that the directors had used fraudulent accounting methods to push up the stock price. Rebranded MCI Inc, it emerged from bankruptcy in 2004 and the assets were bought by [[Verizon]]. | |- |[[Enron]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|Nov|28}} |[[Energy]] |Directors and executives fraudulently concealed large losses in Enron's projects. A number were sentenced to prison.<ref name="hist"/><ref name=MBCF>{{citation |author=Cohen, Jeffrey R., Ding, Yuan, Lesage, Cédric and Stolowy, Hervé |title=Managers' Behavior in Corporate Fraud |date=August 1, 2008 |ssrn=1160076}}</ref> | $63.4 billion |- |[[Chiquita Brands Int]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2001|Nov|28}} |[[Food]] |Accumulated debts, after a series of accusations relating to breaches of labour and environmental standards. It entered a [[pre-packaged insolvency]], and emerged with similar management in 2002.<ref>'Chiquita files bankruptcy under pre-arranged plan' (11 November 2001) [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/general/2001/11/28/chiquita-bankruptcy.htm USA Today]</ref> | |- |[[Kmart]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2002|Jan|22}} |[[Retail]] |After difficult competition, the store was put into [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy proceedings, but soon re-emerged. | |- |[[Adelphia Communications]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2002|Feb|13}} |[[Cable television]] |Internal corruption. The Directors were sentenced to prison.<ref name="MBCF"/><ref name=Forbes>{{citation |url=https://www.forbes.com/2002/07/25/accountingtracker.html |publisher=Forbes |title=The Corporate Scandal Sheet |author=Penelope Patsuris |date=26 August 2002}}</ref> | |- |[[Arthur Andersen]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2002|June|15}} |[[Accounting]] |A US court convicted Andersen of [[obstruction of justice]] by shredding documents relating to [[Enron scandal]]. | |- |[[Parmalat]] |{{flagicon|ITA|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2003|Dec|24}} |[[Food]] |The company's finance directors concealed large debts. | |- |[[MG Rover Group]] |{{flagicon|UK}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2005|April|15}} |[[Automobile]]s |After diminishing demand, and getting a £6.5m loan from the UK government in April 2005, the company went into [[Administration in United Kingdom law|administration]]. After the loss of 30,000 jobs, [[Nanjing Automobile Group]] bought the company's assets. | |- |[[Bayou Hedge Fund Group]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2005|Sep|29}} |[[Hedge fund]] |[[Samuel Israel III]] defrauded his investors into thinking there were higher returns, and orchestrated fake audits. The [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] filed a court complaint and the business was shut down after the directors were caught attempting to send $100m into overseas bank accounts. | |- |[[Refco]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2005|Oct|17}} |[[Brokering]] |After becoming a public company in August 2005, it was revealed that [[Phillip R. Bennett]], the company CEO and chair, had concealed $430m of bad debts. Its underwriters were [[Credit Suisse First Boston]], [[Goldman Sachs]], and [[Bank of America Corp]]. The company entered [[Chapter 11]] and Bennett was sentenced to 16 years prison. | |- |[[Bear Stearns]] |{{flagicon|USA|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Mar|14}} |[[Banking]] |Bear Stearns invested in the sub-prime mortgage market from 2003 after the US government had begun to deregulate consumer protection and derivative trading. The business collapsed as more people began to be unable to meet mortgage obligations. After a stock price high of $172 a share, it was bought by [[JP Morgan]] for $2 a share on 16 March 2008, with a $29bn loan facility guaranteed by the [[US Federal Reserve]]. | |- |[[Northern Rock]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Feb|22}} |[[Banking]] |Northern Rock had invested in the international markets for [[sub-prime mortgage debt]], and as more and more people defaulted on their home loans in the US, the Rock's business collapsed. It triggered the first [[bank run]] in the UK since Overend, Gurney & Co in 1866, when it asked the UK government for assistance. It was nationalised, and then sold to [[Virgin Money UK|Virgin Money]] in 2012. | |- |[[Lehman Brothers]] |{{flagicon|USA|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Sep|15}} |[[Banking]] |Lehman Brothers' financial strategy in from 2003 was to invest heavily in [[mortgage debt]], in markets which were being deregulated from [[consumer protection]] by the [[US government]]. Losses mounted, and Lehman Brothers was forced to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy after the [[US government]] refused to extend a loan. The collapse triggered a global financial market meltdown. [[Barclays]], [[Nomura]] and [[Bain Capital]] purchased the assets which were not indebted. | |- |[[American International Group|AIG]]<ref name=MBCF/> |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Sep|16}} |[[Insurance]] |Out of $441 billion worth of securities originally rated AAA, as the US [[sub-prime mortgage crisis]] unfolded, AIG found it held $57.8 billion of these products. It was forced to take a 24-month credit facility from the US [[Federal Reserve Board]]. | |- |[[Washington Mutual]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Sep|26}} |[[Banking]] |Following the [[sub-prime mortgage crisis]], there was a [[bank run]] on WaMu, and pressure from the FDIC forced closure. | |- |[[Royal Bank of Scotland Group]] |{{flagicon|UK|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Oct|13}} |[[Banking]] |Following the takeover of [[ABN-Amro]], and the collapse of [[Lehman Bros]], RBS found itself insolvent as the international credit market seized up. 58% of the shares were bought by the UK government. | |- |[[ABN-Amro]] |{{flagicon|NED|}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Oct|}} |[[Banking]] |After a takeover battle between [[Banco Santander]], [[Fortis (finance)|Fortis]] and [[Royal Bank of Scotland Group|RBS]], ABN-Amro was split up and divided between the banking consortium. Fortis and RBS were found to be heavily indebted due to the [[sub-prime mortgage crisis]]. Fortis was split and the Dutch part of Fortis was taken under government ownership by The Netherlands, thus reinstating the company in ABN-AMRO. The Belgian part was taken over by [[BNP-Paribas]]. RBS was taken under government ownership by the UK. | |- |[[Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities LLC]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008|Dec|}} |[[Securities]] | Tricked investors out of $64.8 billion through the largest Ponzi scheme in history.
Investors were paid returns out of their own money or that of other investors rather than from profits.
[[Bernard_Madoff|Madoff]] told his sons about his scheme and they reported him to the SEC. He was arrested the next day. |$64.8 billion |- |[[Bankwest]] |{{flagicon|AUS}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2008||}} |[[Banking]] |Following the purchase of Bankwest by the [[Commonwealth Bank Of Australia]] (CBA), there have been calls for a royal commission specifically into the conduct of bank following allegations made that the CBA engineered defaults of Bankwest customers in order to profit from clawback clauses under the purchase agreement. | |- |[[Nortel]] |{{flagicon|CAN}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2009|Jan|14}} |[[Telecomms]] |Following the [[2007-2008 financial crisis]], and allegations over excessive [[executive pay]], demand for products dropped. | |- |[[Anglo Irish Bank]] |{{flagicon|IRL}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2009|Jan|15}} |[[Banking]] |After the financial crisis of 2007-2008, the bank was forced to be nationalised by the Irish government. | |- |[[Arcandor]] |{{flagicon|GER}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2009|June|9}} |[[Retail]] |After struggling to maintain business levels at its brand names [[Karstadt]] and [[KaDeWe]], Arcandor sought help from the German government, and then filed for insolvency. | |- |[[Schlecker]] |{{flagicon|GER}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2012|Jan|23}} |[[Retail]] |After continual losses mounting from 2011 Schlecker, with 52,000 employees, was forced into insolvency, though continued to run. | |- |[[Dynegy]] |{{flagicon|USA}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2012|July|6}} |[[Energy]] |After a series of attempted takeover bids, and a finding of fraud in a subsidiary's purchase of another subsidiary, it filed for [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy. It emerged from bankruptcy on 2 October 2012. | |- |[[China Medical Technologies]] (CMED) |{{flagicon|CAY}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2012|July|27}} |[[Medical technology]] |In 2009, an anonymous letter alleging possible illegal and fraudulent activities by management since 2007 was sent to [[KPMG]] Hong Kong, then CMED's auditor, and investigated by law firm [[Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison]]. Since 27 July 2012, pursuant to an Order by the [[Government_of_the_Cayman_Islands#Judicial_branch|Grand Court of the Cayman Islands]], CMED has been under the control of Joint Official Liquidators. Post-bankruptcy filing, CMED's liquidator found itself probing an alleged $355 million insider fraud. In March 2017, the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] criminally indicted the CMED founder and CEO, as well as former Chief Financial Officer, charging them with [[securities fraud]] and [[wire fraud]] conspiracy for stealing more than $400 million from investors as part of a seven-year scheme. | |- |[[Banco Espírito Santo]] (BES) |{{flagicon|POR}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2014|August|3}} |Banking |An audit performed in 2013, for a capital raise performed in May 2014, uncovered severe financial irregularities and a precarious financial situation of the bank. In July 2014, Salgado was replaced by economist [[Vítor Bento]], who saw BES in an irrecoverable situation. Its good assets were bought by [[Novo Banco]], a vehicle founded by Portugal's financial regulators for that purpose, on August 3, which hired Bento as CEO, while its toxic assets stayed in the "old" BES, which got its banking license revoked by Portugal's regulators. | |- |[[Dick Smith (retailer)]] |{{flagicon|AUS}} |{{dts|format=dmy|2016|January|5}} |[[Retail]] |On 5 January 2016, the retailer collapsed and was placed into [[receivership]]. McGrathNicol were appointed as [[Administrator (law)|administrators]] by the company's board and [[Ferrier Hodgson]] appointed by the company's major creditors [[National Australia Bank]] (NAB) and [[HSBC Bank Australia]]. | |} <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER -->
==List of scandals without insolvency== * [[Australia and New Zealand Banking Group]] scandal involving misleading file notes in the [[Financial Ombudsman Service (Australia)]] presented to the Victorian Supreme Court.<ref name="abc.net.au">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-01/long-the-questions-the-financial-ombudsman-needs-to-answer/7292044|title=The questions the Financial Ombudsman needs to answer|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> * [[Australia and New Zealand Banking Group]] allegations of racial bigotry toward billionaire businessman [[Pankaj Oswal]] and his wife. Court was presented with emails where an ANZ staff member comments to ANZ CEO Mike Smith: "We are dealing with Indians with no moral compass and an Indian woman as every bit as devious as PO (Mr Oswal)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/anz-displayed-racial-bigotry-to-oswals-court-hears/news-story/c819f8f965c1e2876276fd64998a0385|title=ANZ Displayed Racial Bigotry to Oswals Court Hears|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/business/banking/emails-expose-bankers-racist-insults-about-oswals-court/news-story/fd2ad8bcc4644e5f13362885966c3cfe|title=Emails Expose Bankers Racist Insults About Oswals|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/yourlanguage/punjabi/en/article/2016/06/02/anz-accused-racial-bigotry-against-indian-billionaire-couple|title=ANZ Accused Racial Bigotry Against Indian Billionaire Couple|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * [[Australia and New Zealand Banking Group]] toxic culture. Court case where allegations were made by ex-employees that the bank's senior management tolerated drugs and strip clubs.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ANZ facing $30m lawsuit over 'toxic' culture of sleaze|url = http://www.news.com.au/finance/business/banking/anz-facing-30-million-lawsuit-from-sacked-employee-over-toxic-culture-of-sleaze-report/news-story/1ba58a5de6b3a6a28a8be6e5092cd124|website = NewsComAu|access-date = 2016-01-17}}</ref> * [[Australia and New Zealand Banking Group]] alleged manipulation of the Australian benchmark interest rates. ANZ is currently being pursued by the [[Australian Securities and Investments Commission]], which filed an originating process in the Federal Court of Australia against ANZ in March 2016.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-11/corporate-watchdog-investigation-on-bank-rate/7159990 | title = Corporate watchdog investigation on bank rate rigging nears end | website = ABC News | language = en-AU | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.heraldsun.com.au/business/asic-expected-to-launch-legal-action-against-anz-over-alleged-interest-rate-manipulation/news-story/7de77975c41fbd3ff5456774db1c106b | title = Herald Sun | last = Walley | first = Jeff | date = | work = | access-date = 26 February 2016 | via = }}</ref><ref>ASIC, Originating Process available at, http://download.asic.gov.au/media/3563864/originating-process-asicvanz.pdf</ref> * [[BAE Systems#Corruption investigations|BAE Systems]] bribery scandal related to the [[Al-Yamamah arms deal]] with Saudi Arabia * [[Bayer]], links to [[Josef Mengele]]'s [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]] human experiments, HIV-tainted blood products, anti-Semitism, racism, [[Zyklon B]] production through [[IG Farben]] * [[Bristol-Myers Squibb#Scandals and allegations|Bristol-Myers Squibb]] accounting scandal<ref name=Forbes/> * [[Brown & Williamson#Controversy|Brown & Williamson]], for chemically enhancing the addictiveness of cigarettes, becoming the leading edge of the tobacco industry scandals of the 1990s, eventually resulting in the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement]] * [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]]-[[Texaco]] [[Lago Agrio oil field]] pollution scandal * [[Commonwealth Bank|Commonwealth Bank of Australia]] facts uncovered that showed the insurance arm of the bank denied life insurance policy holders despite having legitimate claims, resulting in calls for a Royal Commission into the Australian insurance industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-03-08/comminsure-scandal-cause-for-royal-commission-labor-says/7228136|title=Calls for Royal commission into 'disgraceful' CommInsure|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> * [[Commonwealth Bank Of Australia]] provision of unsuitable financial advice to a large number of customers between 2003 and 2012 and continuious delay in providing compensation to victims.<ref>{{Cite web|title = CBA compensation to victims of financial scandal 'a joke'|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-28/cba-denying-compensation-to-victims-of-financial-planning/6892624|website = ABC News|access-date = 2016-01-17|language = en-AU}}</ref> * [[Compass Group#2005 United Nations misconduct incident|Compass Group]], bribed the [[United Nations]] in order to win business * [[Corrib gas controversy]] Kilcommon, Erris, Co.
